learning_outcomes.description: Evaluate the globalisation process, including its causes, effects, plaudits, and criticisms.
Evaluate the roles and ethical responsibilities of enterprises, governments, consumers, and multilateral organisations in globalisation.
Formulate critical responses to tame wicked problems and grand challenges.
Collaborate effectively to consider and respect diverse stakeholders.
Articulate insights based on evidence, fact, and logical inference to influence change.

assessments.task_description:
The class will be divided into teams and each pair of teams will debate an issue relevant to the course topic for that week (team and individual members assessed). The schedule of debates with group members, dates and topics will be finalised in advance of the debates and posted to the Blackboard in due course. More details will be provided in class. A 'practice debate' opportunity will be provided in Week 3.

Students can use palm cards with key points only (i.e., not the entire debate speech or full paragraphs), and should not be reading off sheets of paper or phones/mobile devices, audience engagement is critical and marks will be deducted if these instructions are not followed. Each individual hands-up their own palm cards following their debate presentation. Each individual should also submit the research that they have undertaken in preparation for their debate (with references and acknowledgement of any AI use) and submit this on Blackboard in advance of their debate (a template will be provided on the Blackboard).

Each team must submit their team charter (in hard copy) on the day of their debate, so that the team can receive a mark for this assessment. Each team also needs to submit a list of their team and speaker roles in advance of the debate (template and submission link on the Blackboard).

More information on this assessment will be made available on Blackboard.

All team members will be required to complete peer evaluations using BuddyCheck to ensure equal member contributions. Results from these evaluations may impact individual grades.

If you have not yet completed the Working in Teams: A Practical Guide edX course please consider undertaking the course for your own professional development purposes - https://www.edx.org/course/working-in-teams-a-practical-guide

assessments.assessment_title: Innovation in Global Business Systems using Teaming and Design Thinking
assessments.task_description:
Team assessment (the same team as the debates) where students form teams in the early part of semester to tackle an innovation in global business systems challenge - the first pitch will take place during seminars in Week 5 and the second pitch during seminars in Week 12 (the second develops on the first). Teams will be expected to critique other teams' first pitches and submit their reflections as a team following that seminar (further instructions will be provided for teams to complete this formative reflection).

This design of the pitch sequence provides students with time before the first and second pitch to learn content and processes from the course that will enable them to complete the pitches and gain ongoing feedback; the second pitch also builds on the first pitch as part of a design thinking process.

Students need to be involved in the development of a minimum of three (3) templates in class to earn marks for the in-class team preparation component of the assessment that is crucial to the pitch development. Further details will be provided in class and available on the assessment outline on the Blackboard.

One student needs to submit a hard copy team charter on behalf of the team and this must be handed up in class on the day of the first pitch.

Teams need to also submit a pitch deck or infographic map (or other 'punchy' visual material) for their pitch, and this must be submitted by 1pm the day before both pitches (Week 5 and 12) to ensure seamless pitch presentations on the day. Students are encouraged to use minimal text, incorporate visuals, ensure all material is polished, and be creative in their design and presentation approaches. Please contact the course coordinator in exceptional circumstances related to any issues with timely submission of these presentation materials. A reminder to acknowledge any use of AI and the nature of its use.

All team members will be required to complete peer evaluations using Buddycheck to ensure equal member contributions. Results from these evaluations may impact individual grades.

Please Note: The presentation will be recorded for marking purposes as per UQ Policy.

assessments.task_description:
This is an individual assessment task where you will be asked to submit three (3) individual debate reflections. The debate reflection templates will be provided through blackboard. On the template you will need to nominate the debate topic you are selecting for that week (note that there could be two debate topics taking place within one week and you can only select one of those topics to reflect on). Each individual reflection needs to be separately uploaded.

Please focus on the arguments within the debates - rather than the speakers.

Your task for each debate reflection is to: 1) Write-up a brief analysis of key arguments; 2) Explain how the debate challenged your current assumptions; 3) Identify any follow-up thoughts and questions this debate may have prompted; 4) Articulate how this debate has impacted your worldview and ideas about the topic area.

There will also be an additional 'reflection question' that will be presented to students at the end of the class following debates and students need to ensure that this is also addressed / integrated in their reflection.

Note: You are not able to submit a reflection for the week of your own debate. The task is to submit three (3) debate reflections from three (3) separate debate weeks (i.e., you cannot submit two entries for any one week).

You will have two (2) weeks following a particular debate to enter your submission via Blackboard (remember you need to submit three (3) of these in total).

Topic 1 - Global environment

Global environment: A systems perspective. Transdisciplinary approach applying multiple lenses. Complex systems framework for globalisation in a modern world. Institutional perspectives. Analysing the meso, macro and micro in order to frame an emphasis on the macro. Wicked problems and grand challenges in the VUCA world economy.

Topic 12 - The Uber economy in a globalised world and Exam Revision and Techniques

The 'Uber' economy in a globalised world. A 'sharing' and 'trust' economy. Critically evaluating the Uber economy in terms of its impacts on different stakeholders in society and on markets. Business model innovation in global markets and incumbent disruption. The circular economy as a collective business model for sustainable change moving forward?
